title: 105_hr3703
content:
The Act titled "Adams National Historical Park Act of 1998" includes sections on short title, table of contents, findings, definitions, Adams National Historical Park, administration, and authorization of appropriations. Congress established the Adams Mansion National Historic Site in Quincy, Massachusetts in 1946 under the Historic Sites, Buildings, and Antiquities Act. The site was later enlarged and renamed the Adams National Historic Site in 1952. In 1972, the boundaries were expanded by 3.68 acres through Public Law 92-272. In 1978, the National Parks and Recreation Act authorized the Secretary to accept the conveyance of the birthplaces of John Adams and John Quincy Adams in Quincy, Massachusetts. In 1980, Public Law 96-435 allowed the Secretary to accept the conveyance of the United First Parish Church in Quincy, Massachusetts, the burial site of John Adams, Abigail Adams, John Quincy Adams, and Louisa Adams. The birthplaces, burial site, and property of John Adams, Abigail Adams, John Quincy Adams, and Louisa Adams have been preserved without specific legislation, resulting in a multi-site unit of the National Park System. The sites associated with these historical figures deserve recognition as a national historical park. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

Historical park refers to the Adams National Historical Park established in section 4.
Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior.

SEC. 4. ADAMS NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK. The Adams National Historical Park is established in Quincy, Massachusetts to preserve properties associated with John Adams, Abigail Adams, John Quincy Adams, and Louisa Adams. The park includes all National Park Service-owned properties in the Adams National Historic Site and those authorized for acquisition. The Adams National Historical Park in Quincy, Massachusetts preserves properties linked to John Adams, Abigail Adams, John Quincy Adams, and Louisa Adams. The Secretary can acquire up to 10 acres for visitor and administrative facilities near the park's main features. The map of the park is available for public inspection. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION. The park will be administered by the Secretary in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park Service Organic Act and the Historic Sites, Buildings, and Antiquities Act. The Secretary can enter into cooperative agreements for preservation and development of the historical park, with payments subject to conditions. The Secretary can acquire real property within the historical park boundaries for its purposes, with payments subject to conditions for reimbursement if the project is used contrary to its established purposes. The Secretary can acquire real property within the historical park boundaries through various methods such as purchase, donation, or land exchange. Certain administrative authorities are repealed, and references to the Adams National Historic Site are now considered references to the historical park. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums may be appropriated for the historical park's operations, maintenance, property acquisition, and facility development as outlined in an approved management plan.
